title: Ticket #6396: noop_job in submit isn't honored by schedd when a claim is reused
description:
For reference: submit value noop_job is translated to IsNoopJob in the job ad.

When the schedd sees a job with IsNoopJob==True, it marks it as completed and goes on its merry way.

However, it does this in count_a_job(), which works for most jobs, but is not sufficient for all jobs. Particularly, when reusing a claim, it is possible to have a noop job that count_a_job() has not yet processed (because it was recently submitted), so the schedd goes ahead and executes the job as if this attribute were not present.

We need to check for the IsNoopJob attribute when searching for a runnable job. For efficient processing of IsNoopJob, we should also be checking just after the job is submitted.

Now the way the schedd finds jobs to run when it gets match records is to walk the PrioRec array checking each job in order. this guarantees that the highest priority matching job gets the match. In 8.6.6 and earlier versions of the schedd. noop jobs are put into the PrioRec array, so FindRunnableJob finds them. If they were skipped when building the PrioRec array, then they would not be run, although because the IsNoopJob is an expression, it should still be checked in Runnable to insure that even if a job ends up in the PrioRec array, it will not be run.
remarks:
2017-Sep-06 17:03:17 by zmiller:
To reproduce, open attachment and submit a.dag, let it run to completion. When the bug is present, jobs N3 and N4 will execute even though they are marked noop, and you'll see result files output.N2, output.N3, and output.N4.

If the bug is fixed, you should see only output.N2.

(run clean in between trials to remove output, logs, dagman cruft.)

2017-Sep-07 11:21:09 by johnkn:
One way to avoid hitting this bug is to make sure that the noop jobs don't match any resources. This can be accomplished by setting requirements=false as well as noop_job=true to the submit file.

2017-Sep-07 12:47:11 by johnkn:
The fix (for stable) will be to skip the noop jobs when building the PrioRec array, and ALSO to check for noop jobs in Runnable. This will prevent jobs that were submitted as noop jobs from being found when searching for runnable jobs, and also prevent them from being run if the IsNoopJob expression changes to true after the PrioRec array is built, but before the job is actually started.
